title: Reginaldo Haslett-Marroquin -- Decolonizing and Indigenizing Regenerative Agriculture (part 2 of 3)

tasks.task: Engage in decolonized regenerative agriculture practices.
subtasks: Shift from conventional agronomy to indigenous knowledge systems.
Abandon extractive processes and adopt perpetual resource management.
Foster social and economic independence at the community level.
Validate ancestral traditions, knowledge, and wisdom for collective wellbeing.
Design supply chains that prioritize local and regional governance.
Implement systems of mutual accountability and interdependency.
Focus on holistic health rather than disease management.
Share wealth and benefits collectively, rather than extracting profits.
Transition from livestock confinement to free-range, shaded environments.
Integrate natural processes for energy transformation (e.g., photosynthesis, nutrient cycling).
Develop systems resilient to global environmental issues (e.g., climate change, water pollution).
Promote consumer engagement and autonomous food systems.
Expand regional collective enterprises for processing and distribution.
Challenge corporate dominance and financial exploitation in agriculture.
Prioritize nutrition over profit in food production.
Operate with a triple-bottom-line approach (ecological, economic, social).
